explanation:
strerror — This is a <string.h> function used in the code. You must confirm its semantics (it returns a pointer to a null-terminated static string and does not write into caller buffers) to determine whether its use can lead to any out‑of‑bounds access.

errno — The argument passed to strerror. Understand the errno usage to ensure no indirect misuse of strerror that could trigger undefined behavior.

OS_DEBUG — The logging macro/function that consumes the string returned by strerror using "%s". You need its prototype/behavior (does it do additional processing, use custom formatters, or copy into fixed buffers) to determine whether it could read past the returned string or otherwise invoke string.h operations.

GENERIC_IO_CONST_DATA_CAST — Macro used on the buffer argument to write(). Verify it is a plain cast (not wrapping a call to a string.h routine or performing pointer arithmetic) so that no implicit string function is applied to the user buffer.

OS_OBJECT_TABLE_GET — Macro used to obtain impl. Verify this expansion does not involve any string.h functions or manipulate the buffer pointer in a way relevant to the rule.

OS_impl_file_internal_record_t — Definition of the impl structure (fields fd, selectable). Needed to confirm that impl->fd/selectable accesses are straightforward and that no hidden string operations occur when accessing impl data.

OS_impl_filehandle_table — The table object used by OS_OBJECT_TABLE_GET. Needed to ensure the table lookup is not invoking string.h routines that could access buffers out of bounds.

OS_SelectSingle_Impl — Called when selectable is true; it may affect control flow. Confirm it does not call any <string.h> functions on the same buffer or otherwise introduce potential out‑of‑bounds string operations.

write — The system call used to output the buffer. Confirm its prototype and semantics (it treats the buffer as raw bytes and does not call string.h functions), to rule out any string.h related bounds issues there.

OS_STREAM_STATE_WRITABLE, OS_SUCCESS, OS_ERROR — Constants used to determine control flow into the strerror/OS_DEBUG branch and the write() branch. Knowing the control-flow conditions is necessary to see whether the string.h call (strerror) can be reached and under what circumstances.

Rationale: The MISRA rule targets uses of the standard string.h functions that can access beyond object bounds. The only direct string.h usage in the target function is strerror (and any formatting/processing in OS_DEBUG). The above symbols let an analyzer confirm the exact behavior of strerror and the logging path, verify there are no hidden string.h calls in macros or object-table lookups, and ensure the buffer passed to write() is not additionally handled by any string functions.
